patient_information: The patient, a 52-year-old male with type 2 diabetes mellitus and poorly controlled hypertension, has a recent travel history to Vietnam several years ago. His last travel outside the city was also several years ago.
chief_complaint: The patient's chief complaint is a retro-orbital headache that has persisted for four days, accompanied by lethargy, myalgia, and fevers.
history_of_present_illness: The patient's timeline over the past four days reveals a series of symptoms including fever, headache, malaise, and myalgia. The severity pattern appears to show an apparent progression towards a severe condition characterized by vascular leak and compensated shock.
exposure_and_epidemiology: The place of residence and travel is in Vietnam. There are vector exposures, which include mosquito exposure due to the endemic setting. However, there are no animal exposures or water-food risks mentioned. No contacts have been identified. The season and outbreak context are not specified. Occupation information is also missing.
vitals: The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.5 degrees Celsius, blood pressure of 105 over 90 millimeters of mercury, heart rate of 120 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation level of 93% when breathing air.
physical_exam: The physical examination revealed a drowsy but rousable patient with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 14/15. The temperature was recorded at 36.5°C, blood pressure at 105/90 mmHg, heart rate at 120 beats per minute, and respiratory rate at 28 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation was noted to be 93% on air with a peripheral oxygen saturation of the same value. The radial pulse was weak, but heart sounds were normal. Abdominal distension was mild, and there was shifting dullness present. The liver edge was tender and measured 3 cm in size, indicating mild hepatomegaly. The gallbladder wall appeared thickened. The skin examination did not reveal any abnormalities.
labs_and_diagnostics: The laboratory results indicate that the patient's hemoglobin level is 14.6 grams per deciliter, hematocrit is 53.9%, platelet count is 58 × 10^9/L, white blood cell count (WCC) is 2.1 × 10^9/L, neutrophils are 0.9 × 10^9/L, lymphocytes are 0.8 × 10^9/L, C-reactive protein level is 20 mg/L, urea is 7.8 millimoles per liter, creatinine is 114 micromoles per liter, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is 812 units per liter, alkaline phosphatase is 260 units per liter, total bilirubin is 18 micromoles per liter, and lactate is 3.5 millimoles per liter.
differential_diagnosis: The differential diagnosis includes Dengue fever, Chikungunya, and Malaria. For Dengue, the reasons include a short duration of symptoms before presentation, relatively low C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, and absence of neutrophil leucocytosis. Clinical signs of shock such as tachycardia, narrow pulse pressure less than 20 mmHg, reduced Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), and raised serum lactate are also considered. Chikungunya is considered due to its epidemiology in South East Asia and the possibility of sepsis. Malaria is ruled out by the absence of evidence of haemolysis that would support this diagnosis and the low risk of malaria in most urban areas of Vietnam.
management_and_clinical_course: The management and clinical course involves the administration of Ringer's lactate solution at a volume of 10 mL/kg over one hour. The rate of fluid delivery is initially set to 15 mL/kg/hr until sufficient haemodynamic improvement is shown, then adjusted to 7 mL/kg/hr for two hours followed by an increase of 2 mL/kg/hr every two hours until no longer required. Clinical assessments include haematocrit checks every six hours. The patient is discharged three days later after complete recovery.
final_diagnosis: The final diagnosis is Dengue fever, caused by the Dengue virus. The confirmation methods include detection of the NS1 antigen using RDTs or ELISA, and detection of viral RNA through RT-PCR. Evidence for alternatives has been ruled out, as there is no evidence of haemolysis to support a malaria diagnosis, and the risk of malaria in most urban areas of Vietnam is very low.
disease_name_short: The disease_name_short for Dengue fever is "Dengue fever".
